docs.title: AGNBoost
docs.text: A powerful machine learning toolkit for astronomical data analysis using advanced XGBoost techniques.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AGNBoost is a specialized Python package designed for astronomers working with photometric data. Built on the foundation of XGBoostLSS, AGNBoost provides a streamlined workflow for disitrubtional regression with photometric data, with particular focus on Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) identification and galaxy property estimation.

Whether you're analyzing JWST observations, conducting large-scale surveys, or developing custom models for your research, AGNBoost offers the tools and flexibility you need to extract meaningful insights from your astronomical data.

Quick Start

New to AGNBoost? Check out our Quick Start Guide to get up and running in minutes!

docs.title: 🔭 Astronomy-Focused Data Management
docs.text:
• Smart Catalog System: Load and manage astronomical data from FITS files, CSV, or pandas DataFrames
  • Band Configuration: Flexible JSON-based configuration for photometric bands with metadata (wavelengths, shorthand names)
  • Automatic Feature Engineering: Built-in color calculations, magnitude transformations, and signal-to-noise filtering
  • Data Validation: Ensures data quality and compatibility across different datasets

docs.title: 🚀 Advanced Machine Learning Pipeline
docs.text:
• Hyperparameter Optimization: Intelligent tuning with custom parameter grids and early stopping
  • Cross-Validation: Robust model validation with stratified splitting for both classification and regression
  • Model Persistence: Comprehensive saving and loading with full metadata tracking

docs.title: ⚡ XGBoostLSS Integration
docs.text:
• Distributional Modeling: Go beyond point estimates with full probability distributions
  • Custom Objectives: Specialized loss functions for astronomical applications
  • Efficient Training: Optimized for large astronomical datasets with GPU acceleration support
  • Uncertainty Quantification: Robust uncertainty estimates for Astronomical analysis

docs.title: 🛠 Research-Ready Tools
docs.text:
• Flexible Data Splitting: Train/validation/test splits with optional stratification
  • Signal-to-Noise Filtering: Built-in S/N cuts for photometric data quality control
  • Transform Pipeline: Easy-to-use data transformation and augmentation tools
  • Extensible Architecture: Designed for customization and integration with existing workflows

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: We recommend using a virtual environment to manage dependencies. AGNBoost works best with Python 3.10/3.11 or later.

docs.title: Using Conda (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Create a new conda environment
conda create -n agnboost python=3.11
conda activate agnboost

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/agnboost.git
cd agnboost

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

docs.title: Using pip and venv
docs.text:
# Create a virtual environment
python -m venv agnboost-env
source agnboost-env/bin/activate  # On Windows: agnboost-env\Scripts\activate

# Clone and install
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/agnboost.git
cd agnboost
pip install -e .

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
import agnboost
from agnboost import Catalog, AGNBoost

print(f"AGNBoost version: {agnboost.__version__}")

Development Installation

The -e flag installs AGNBoost in "editable" mode, which means changes to the source code will be immediately available without reinstalling. This is particularly useful if you plan to contribute to the project or customize it for your research.

docs.title: Built on XGBoostLSS
docs.text:
AGNBoost leverages the power of XGBoostLSS, a cutting-edge extension of XGBoost that enables distributional modeling. Instead of predicting single point estimates, XGBoostLSS models the entire conditioan distributions, providing:

  • Full Distributional Predictions: Estimate not just the mean, but the entire shape of the target distribution
  • Robust Uncertainty Quantification: Get principled uncertainty estimates for your astronomical measurements
  • Flexible Distributions: Choose from a wide variety of probability distributions tailored to your data
  • Advanced Regularization: Built-in techniques to prevent overfitting and improve generalization

This makes AGNBoost particularly powerful for astronomical applications where uncertainty quantification is crucial, such as:

  • Photometric redshift estimation with confidence intervals
  • AGN identification with uncertainty bounds
  • Stellar mass estimation with full posterior distributions

docs.text:

    New to AGNBoost? Start with our comprehensive tutorial covering installation, basic usage, and your first analysis.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: View Tutorials

  • :material-code-braces:{ .lg .middle } API Reference

    Complete documentation of all classes, methods, and functions in AGNBoost.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: API Docs

  • :material-telescope:{ .lg .middle } Examples

    Real-world examples using JWST data, custom features, and advanced modeling techniques.

    :octicons-arrow-right-24: See Examples

docs.title: Community and Support
docs.text:
AGNBoost is developed by astronomers, for astronomers. We welcome contributions, feedback, and collaboration from the community.

  • GitHub Repository: github.com/yourusername/agnboost
  • Issues and Discussions: Use GitHub Issues for bug reports and feature requests
  • Contributing: See our Contributing Guide to get involved

AGNBoost is open-source software released under the MIT License. If you use AGNBoost in your research, please see our Citation Guide.

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This page provides complete documentation for all AGNBoost classes and functions.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AGNBoost consists of two main classes:

  • Catalog: For data loading, management, and feature engineering
  • AGNBoost: For machine learning model training, tuning, and prediction

docs.title: Catalog Class
docs.text: The Catalog class is your entry point for working with astronomical data. It handles loading data from various formats, validates photometric bands, creates features, and manages data splits.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Load FITS files, CSV files, or pandas DataFrames
  • Automatic photometric band validation
  • Feature engineering (colors, transformations)
  • Train/validation/test data splitting
  • Signal-to-noise filtering

A class for loading, managing, and manipulating astronomical data.

The Catalog class provides tools for loading astronomical data from various formats, performing feature engineering, data validation, and preparing data for machine learning workflows. It supports FITS files, CSV files, and pandas DataFrames.

Attributes:

Name Type Description data DataFrame

The main astronomical dataset.

features_df DataFrame

Engineered features for machine learning.

valid_columns dict

Metadata for validated photometric band columns.

train_indices Index

Indices for training data split.

val_indices Index

Indices for validation data split.

test_indices Index

Indices for test data split.

Examples:

Basic usage with a FITS file:

from agnboost import Catalog

# Load data
catalog = Catalog(path="jwst_data.fits")

# Create features
catalog.create_feature_dataframe()

# Split data
catalog.split_data(test_size=0.2, val_size=0.2)

Loading data from a pandas DataFrame:

```python import pandas as pd df = pd.read_csv("data.csv") catalog = Catalog(data=df) '''

docs.title: create_color_dataframe staticmethod
docs.text:
create_color_dataframe(data, bands)

Calculate photometric colors from band fluxes.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame DataFrame containing color columns.

docs.title: create_feature_dataframe
docs.text:
create_feature_dataframe(feature_funcs=None)

Create a dataframe of features for eventual use with AGNBoost class.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: feature_funcs : list or None List of functions to apply to the validated columns. If None, default features (log10 of bands, colors, and square of colors) are created.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame The created feature dataframe (also stored as self.features_df).

docs.title: transform
docs.text:
transform(column_name, transform_func, new_column_name=None, inplace=False)

Apply a transformation function to a column and save the result.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: column_name : str Name of the column to transform. transform_func : callable Function to apply to the column. new_column_name : str or None, default=None Name for the transformed column. If None and not inplace, will use f"{column_name}_transformed". inplace : bool, default=False If True, overwrite the original column. If False, create a new column.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.Series The transformed column.

docs.title: get_targets
docs.text:
get_targets(target_names)

Extract target columns from the data.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: target_names : str or list Name(s) of target column(s) to extract. drop_na : bool, default=False If True, drop rows with NA values in any of the target columns.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame or pandas.Series Target column(s). Returns a Series if a single target name is provided, or a DataFrame if multiple targets are requested.

docs.title: get_features
docs.text:
get_features()

Get the feature dataframe, creating it if it doesn't exist.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame The feature dataframe.

docs.title: get_feature_names
docs.text:
get_feature_names()

Get the feature names dataframe, creating it if it doesn't exist.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame The feature dataframe.

docs.title: print_data_summary
docs.text:
print_data_summary()

Print a formatted summary of the loaded data.

docs.title: get_valid_bands
docs.text:
get_valid_bands()

Get information about valid band columns in the data.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary of valid band columns with their metadata.

docs.title: get_valid_bands_list
docs.text:
get_valid_bands_list()

Get information about valid band columns in the data.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary of valid band columns with their metadata.

docs.title: get_band_wavelengths
docs.text:
get_band_wavelengths()

Get a dictionary mapping band columns to their wavelengths.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary mapping column names to wavelengths in microns.

docs.title: get_band_shorthands
docs.text:
get_band_shorthands()

Get a dictionary mapping band columns to their shorthand names.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary mapping column names to shorthand identifiers.

docs.title: sn_cut
docs.text:
sn_cut(columns=None, threshold=3.0, inplace=False, suffix='_err')

Perform a signal-to-noise ratio cut on the specified columns.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: columns : dict or None Dictionary mapping value columns to their error columns. Example: {'flux': 'flux_err', 'redshift': 'redshift_err'} If None, automatically detect band columns and use {band: band+suffix} pairs. threshold : float, default=3.0 Minimum S/N ratio to keep a row. inplace : bool, default=False If True, modifies the data in place; otherwise, returns a copy. suffix : str, default='_err' Suffix to append to band names to find error columns, if columns=None.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame or None Filtered dataframe if inplace=False, otherwise None.

docs.title: get_data
docs.text:
get_data()

Return the loaded dataframe.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame The loaded data.

docs.title: get_columns
docs.text:
get_columns()

Return the column names of the loaded dataframe.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: list List of column names.

docs.title: filter_data
docs.text:
filter_data(filter_conditions)

Filter the data based on provided conditions.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: filter_conditions : dict Dictionary of column:value pairs to filter on.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame Filtered dataframe.

docs.title: get_subset
docs.text:
get_subset(columns=None, rows=None)

Get a subset of the data by columns and/or rows.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: columns : list or None List of column names to include. If None, includes all columns. rows : slice, list, or None Rows to include. Can be a slice (e.g., slice(0, 100)), a list of indices, or None to include all rows.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame Subset of the data.

docs.title: save_to_csv
docs.text:
save_to_csv(output_path, index=False)

Save the current data to a CSV file.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: output_path : str Path to save the CSV file. index : bool, default=False Whether to include the index in the saved file.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: bool True if successful, False otherwise.

docs.title: drop_nan
docs.text:
drop_nan(columns=None, inplace=False, how='any')

Drop rows with NaN values in specified columns or validated columns.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: columns : list or None, default=None List of column names to check for NaN. If None, uses all validated columns. inplace : bool, default=False If True, performs operation in-place and returns None. If False, returns a copy of the data with rows dropped. how : {'any', 'all'}, default='any' 'any' : Drop if any of the specified columns has NaN 'all' : Drop only if all of the specified columns have NaN

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame or None The DataFrame with NaN rows dropped, or None if inplace=True.

docs.title: split_data
docs.text:
split_data(test_size=0.2, val_size=0.2, random_state=None, stratify_col=None, n_bins=10)

Split the data into train, validation, and test sets.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: test_size : float, default=0.2 Proportion of the data to use for testing (0.0 to 1.0). val_size : float, default=0.2 Proportion of the data to use for validation (0.0 to 1.0). random_state : int or None, default=None Random seed for reproducibility. stratify_col : str or None, default=None Column name to use for stratified splitting. If provided, ensures proportional representation of this column's values in all splits. For continuous columns, binning will be applied. n_bins : int, default=10 Number of bins to use when stratifying on a continuous column. Only used when stratify_col is a continuous variable.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: tuple (train_indices, val_indices, test_indices) - Indices for each split

docs.title: get_split_df
docs.text:
get_split_df(split_type='train', include_features=True, include_target=None, return_DMatrix=False, missing=np.nan)

Get a dataframe for the specified data split.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: split_type : str, default='train' Which data split to use. Options: 'train', 'val'/'validation', or 'test'. include_features : bool, default=True If True, include the feature columns in the result. include_target : str, list, or None, default=None Target column(s) to include. If None, no target columns are included. return_DMatrix: bool, default = False Whether to return a XGBoost DMatrix instead of a pandas Dataframe. missing : int, float, or None, default=np.nan Value to represent missing values in XGBoost.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: pandas.DataFrame DataFrame for the specified split with requested columns.

docs.title: get_train_val_test_sizes
docs.text:
get_train_val_test_sizes()

Get the sizes and percentages of the train, validation, and test sets.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary with set sizes and percentages. Format: { 'total': int, 'train': {'size': int, 'percentage': float}, 'validation': {'size': int, 'percentage': float}, 'test': {'size': int, 'percentage': float} }

docs.title: AGNBoost Class
docs.text: The AGNBoost class provides the machine learning functionality, including model training, hyperparameter tuning, and prediction with uncertainty quantification.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• XGBoostLSS integration for distributional modeling
  • Hyperparameter optimization
  • Model persistence and loading
  • Multi-target support
  • Comprehensive logging and validation

docs.title: tune_model
docs.text:
tune_model(model_name, param_grid, dtune, split_type='train', max_minutes=10, nfold=2, early_stopping_rounds=100)

Tune hyperparameters for the specified model.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: model_name : str Name of the model to tune. Must be in self.model_names. param_grid : dict Dictionary of hyperparameter ranges to search. Example: {'max_depth': [3, 5, 7], 'learning_rate': [0.01, 0.1, 0.3]} dtune : xgboost.DMatrix or pandas.DataFrame or Catalog Data to use for tuning. If DataFrame or Catalog, will be converted to DMatrix. max_minutes : int, default=10 Maximum duration for tuning in minutes. nfold : int, default=2 Number of cross-validation folds. early_stopping_rounds : int, default=100 Number of rounds without improvement before early stopping.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary containing best parameters and tuning metrics.

docs.title: train_model
docs.text:
train_model(model_name, dtrain, dval=None, params=None, split_type='train', num_boost_round=1000, early_stopping_rounds=None, verbose_eval=False, custom_objective=None, custom_metric=None)

Train an XGBoost model with the given parameters.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: model_name : str Name of the model to train. Must be in self.model_names. dtrain : xgboost.DMatrix or Catalog Training data. If a Catalog, will create a DMatrix using the specified split. dval : xgboost.DMatrix, bool, or None, default=None Validation data. If a DMatrix, use directly. If True and dtrain is a Catalog, create a validation DMatrix from the Catalog. If False or None, no validation data is used. params : dict or None, default=None Parameters for XGBoost. If None, uses tuned_params from model_info if available, otherwise uses default parameters. split_type : str, default='train' Which data split to use if dtrain is a Catalog. Options: 'train', 'val', 'test'. num_boost_round : int, default=1000 Number of boosting rounds. early_stopping_rounds : int or None, default=50 Number of rounds without improvement before early stopping. If None, no early stopping is used. verbose_eval : int or bool, default=100 Controls XGBoost's logging frequency. If True, prints every round. If int, prints every verbose_eval rounds. If False, no logging. custom_objective : callable or None, default=None Custom objective function for XGBoost. custom_metric : callable or None, default=None Custom evaluation metric for XGBoost.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: tuple (trained_model, training_results)

docs.title: load_model
docs.text:
load_model(file_name, overwrite=False)

Load pre-trained models from disk.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: model_names : list, str, or None, default=None Name(s) of models to load. If None, loads all models in self.model_names. retrain : bool, default=False If True, forces retraining even if models exist.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: bool True if all requested model was loaded successfully, False otherwise.

docs.title: predict
docs.text:
predict(data, model_name, split_use=None, seed=123)

Make predictions using trained models.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: data : DataFrame, Catalog, or dict Data to make predictions on. Can be a pandas DataFrame, a Catalog object, or a dict mapping model names to their specific data. model_name : str or None If provided, use only this model. Otherwise, use all available models.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary of predictions for each model.

docs.title: model_uncertainty staticmethod
docs.text:
model_uncertainty(model: model, data: DMatrix, dist_name: str, best_iter: int, M: int = 1, seed=123) -> np.array

Function that predicts from the trained model.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: model : xgblsslib.model Trained model. data : xgb.DMatrix Data to predict frmodel: xgblsslib.modelom. M : int Number of desired models in virtual ensemble.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: pred : pd.DataFrame Predictions.

docs.title: predict_dist_trunc staticmethod
docs.text:
predict_dist_trunc(dist: DistributionClass, booster: Booster, start_values: ndarray, data: DMatrix, iteration_range: Tuple[int, int] = (0, 0)) -> pd.DataFrame

Function that predicts from therag trained model.

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: booster : xgb.Boosterdist Trained model. start_values : np.ndarray Starting values for each distributional parameter. data : xgb.DMatrix Data to predict from. iteration_range: Tuple[int,int] Which layer of trees to use for prediction in xgb.booster.predict

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: pred : pd.DataFrame Predictions.xgboost model get numeber of boostin rounds

docs.title: list_available_models staticmethod
docs.text:
list_available_models(models_dir=None)

List all available pre-trained models in the models directory.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: models_dir : str or None Directory to look for models. If None, uses the default models directory.

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: dict Dictionary with model names as keys and metadata as values.

docs.title: Utility Functions
docs.text: Helper functions for data processing, feature engineering, and model management.

docs.title: log_message
docs.text:
log_message(message, level='INFO')

Log a message with the specified level.

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: message : str Message to log. level : str Log level (INFO, WARNING, ERROR).

docs.title: validate_param_grid
docs.text:
validate_param_grid(param_grid)

Validate that the parameter grid is correctly formatted.

Expected format: { "param_name": ["type", type_specific_value], ... }

Where "type" is one of: - "none": type_specific_value should be a list of specific values - "int": type_specific_value should be a dict with "low", "high", "log" keys - "float": type_specific_value should be a dict with "low", "high", "log" keys - "categorical": type_specific_value should be a list of possible values

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: param_grid : dict Dictionary of parameter grid specifications

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: tuple (is_valid, error_message) - (True, None) if valid, (False, error_msg) if invalid

docs.title: validate_param_dict
docs.text:
validate_param_dict(params)

Validate that the passed params are a dictionary of single values

Expected format: { "param_name": value, ... }

docs.title: Parameters:
docs.text: params : dict Dictionary of parameter grid specifications

docs.title: Returns:
docs.text: tuple (is_valid, error_message) - (True, None) if valid, (False, error_msg) if invalid

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
docs/getting-started.md: 

# Quick Start

This guide will get you up and running with AGNBoost in just a few minutes.

## Prerequisites

Make sure you have Python 3.8 or later installed and AGNBoost is set up in your environment.

```bash
# Verify your installation
python -c "import agnboost; print('AGNBoost is ready!')"

docs.title: Your First Catalog
docs.text: The Catalog class is the starting point for working with astronomical data in AGNBoost.

docs.title: Loading Data from a File
docs.text:
from agnboost import Catalog

# Load data from a FITS file
catalog = Catalog(path="your_data.fits")

# Or from a CSV file
catalog = Catalog(path="your_data.csv")

# View basic information about your data
catalog.print_data_summary()

docs.title: Loading Data from a DataFrame
docs.text:
If you already have your data in a pandas DataFrame:

import pandas as pd
from agnboost import Catalog

# Load your data however you prefer
df = pd.read_csv("your_data.csv")

# Create a catalog from the DataFrame
catalog = Catalog(data=df)

docs.title: Working with Features
docs.text:
AGNBoost can automatically create features from your photometric data:

# Generate features (colors, log magnitudes, etc.)
catalog.create_feature_dataframe()

# Check what features were created
features = catalog.get_features()
print(f"Created {features.shape[1]} features from {features.shape[0]} objects")

docs.title: Using Pre-trained Models
docs.text:
AGNBoost comes with pre-trained models for common astronomical tasks:

from agnboost import AGNBoost

# Initialize AGNBoost
agnboost = AGNBoost()

# Load pre-trained models
models_loaded = agnboost.load_models()

if models_loaded:
    print("Pre-trained models loaded successfully!")

    # Make predictions
    predictions = agnboost.predict(catalog)
    print("Available predictions:", list(predictions.keys()))
else:
    print("No pre-trained models found. You may need to train new models.")

docs.title: A Complete Example
docs.text:
Here's a complete workflow from data loading to predictions:

from agnboost import Catalog, AGNBoost

# Step 1: Load your data
catalog = Catalog(path="jwst_photometry.fits")
print(f"Loaded {len(catalog.get_data())} astronomical objects")

# Step 2: Create features
catalog.create_feature_dataframe()
print(f"Generated {catalog.get_features().shape[1]} features")

# Step 3: Load pre-trained models
agnboost = AGNBoost()
agnboost.load_models()

# Step 4: Make predictions
predictions = agnboost.predict(catalog)

# Step 5: Access your results
for model_name, preds in predictions.items():
    print(f"Predictions from {model_name} model: {len(preds)} objects")

docs.title: Data Requirements
docs.text:
For AGNBoost to work optimally, your data should include:

  • Photometric measurements: Flux or magnitude values in supported bands
  • Error estimates: Uncertainty values for photometric measurements
  • Valid band names: Column names that match the allowed_bands.json configuration

You can check which bands are recognized:

# See which photometric bands were found in your data
valid_bands = catalog.get_valid_bands()
print("Valid photometric bands found:")
for band_name, info in valid_bands.items():
    print(f"  {band_name}: {info['shorthand']} ({info['wavelength']} μm)")

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Now that you have the basics working, you can:

  • Explore the tutorials: Learn about advanced features and customization
  • Check the API documentation: Deep dive into all available methods and options
  • Train custom models: Use your own data to train specialized models

docs.title: Useful Links
docs.text:
• Band Configuration Tutorial - Learn how to add new photometric bands
  • Training from Scratch Tutorial - Train models on your own data
  • API Reference - Complete documentation of all classes and methods

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
"No valid band columns found": Your data column names don't match the expected photometric band names. Check the Band Configuration Tutorial to learn how to add your bands.

"No pre-trained models found": The models directory is empty or models are incompatible. You may need to train new models or check that the models were properly downloaded.

Import errors: Make sure all dependencies are installed. See the Installation guide for details.

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter issues:

  1. Check the API documentation for detailed method descriptions
  2. Look at the tutorial examples for similar use cases
  3. Open an issue on the GitHub repository
